tossups.question: This person had a walk-on role as the Duchess of Krakenthorp in the National Opera's production of La fille du régiment. This political figure admitted they weren’t “100% sober” after dozing off at the 2015 State of the Union Address and their life is the basis of the 2018 film (*) On The Basis of Sex. This figure garnered fame for fiery dissents which led the Internet to give her the rap-themed nickname "Notorious." Judge Amy Coney Barrett was nominated to one body in the wake of this woman's death. For 10 points, name this figure who championed women's rights as an Associate Justice on the Supreme Court before her September 2020 death.
tossups.answer: Ruth Bader Ginsburg [accept RBG, accept the Notorious RBG]

tossups.question: This novel's title character is stuck in Lisbon in their first appearance, The Voyage Out. Another character in this novel is anguished by a toffee ad in the sky and is aided by Sir Bradshaw and his wife Lucrezia due to his hallucinations of his dead friend Evans. This novel's title character fondly recalls kissing Sally Seton at Bourton and regrets not marrying (*) Peter Walsh. This novel's title character hears of the suicide of the shell-shocked veteran Septimus Smith while at a party. For ten points, name this stream-of-consciousness novel about Clarissa's party by Virginia Woolf.

One of these creatures created the river Van from its saliva. That creature was trapped using an object forged from materials such as the breath of a fish and the beard of a woman. In the Grimnismal, Odin tells Agnarr that he gives all his food to two of these creatures named (*) Geri and Freki, while himself only consuming wine. Another pair named Hati and Skoll chase the moon and sun across the sky. Tyr placed his hand in the mouth of one of these creatures who was bound by the chain Gleipnir. That son of Loki will one day consume Odin at Ragnarok and is named Fenrir. For ten points, name these large canines that often hunt in packs.
tossups.answer: wolf [or wolves; accept wargs; accept Fenrir until “two of these creatures”; prompt on canines until mention; do not accept or prompt on “dogs” since they are not conflated in these myths]
tossups.answer_formatted: wolf [or wolves; accept wargs; accept Fenrir until “two of these creatures; prompt on canines until mention; do not accept or prompt on "dogs”" since they are not conflated in these myths]

tossups.question: These events were observed in E. coli in the absence of selection during the Luria-Delbruck experiment. These events are occasionally responsible for the silencing of transposable elements by hindering movement of genetic elements along chromosomes. Premature insertion of amber, opal, or ochre stop codons would result in the (*) “nonsense” type of these events. Insertions and deletions cause the “frameshift” type of this event. Sickle cell anemia is caused by a “point” type of this event involving substitution of glutamic acid to valine. For ten points, name these events that cause a permanent change in the structure of genes.

During a series of disputes between people of this ethnicity, gangs committed “slave girl” raids. Miners of this ethnicity were killed in the Rock Springs massacre. San Francisco’s Queue Ordinance targeted these people, many of whom formed societies called (*) tongs. Despite the concerns of Charles Crocker, thousands of these people were hired to construct the first Transcontinental Railroad. Benjamin Harrison opposed an 1882 Exclusion Act that aimed to prevent the immigration of people with this ethnicity. For ten points, name this ethnic group that immigrated to the United States from cities like Shanghai.

In one scene in this musical, a character dubbed the “Napoleon of Crime” impersonates another character and later escapes by shorting out the stage light. A former theater actor in this musical recounts a previous performance as a pirate captain on the river Thames. A character describes being (*) “all alone in the moonlight” before declaring “I must wait for the sunrise” in one song in this musical. That song is sung by Jemima and Grizabella and is titled “Memory.” In this musical, one member of the Jellicle tribe is selected to ascend to the Heaviside Layer. For ten points, name this 1981 Andrew Lloyd Webber musical about the title felines.

A leader of this country released a group of prisoners known as the 23 People after the city of Khorramshahr [co-ram-share] was recaptured by their country. Photographer Kaveh Golestan depicted the aftermath of a poison gas attack on this country’s town of Halabja. This country’s plan to build the “Osirak” nuclear reactor was thwarted by Israeli-led forces in Operation (*) Opera. This country’s forces were defeated by an United Nations coalition during the First Gulf War after it invaded Kuwait. This country’s long-time leader often persecuted its Kurdish minority and was captured in Tikrit in 2003. For ten points, name this country once led by Saddam Hussein from Baghdad.

This phenomenon was observed in lithium gas cooled to 150 nanokelvin. In a simplified model of a solid, the Stoner criterion must be met for this phenomenon to occur. Remanence with this phenomenon can be measured by observing the effect of a hysteresis loop. Lars Onsager solved the two dimensional analogue of a model describing this phenomenon called the (*) Ising model. Rare earth metals such as neodymium strongly exhibit this phenomenon. This phenomenon occurs when molecular domains are parallelly aligned in a solid and disappears above the Curie temperature. For ten points, name this form of permanent magnetism exhibited by cobalt, nickel, and its namesake, iron.

One of this composer’s first pieces following his Russian period was an octet for wind and brass instruments. A choral symphony by this composer lacks violins and is titled Symphony of Psalms. A chord named for a ballet by this composer consists of two simultaneously played major triads that are a tritone apart. “The Augurs of Spring” is the first dance in another ballet by this composer of (*) Petrushka. This composer wrote a ballet depicting the sacrifice of a virgin woman as part of a pagan ritual, which sparked riots at its Paris premiere. For ten points, name this composer of The Rite of Spring.

In a 2019 novel, a person with this title has a daughter named Nicole whose adoptive parents are murdered by secret agents. People with this title are overseen by the former judge Lydia in The Testaments. In another novel, Professor Piexoto listens to cassette tapes made by a former holder of this position, a former wife of Luke who is brought to the brothel (*) Jezebel's. That character with this title attempts to escape to Canada with Luke before playing Scrabble with the Commander. For 10 points, Offred holds what title given to fertile women in the state of Gilead in two novels by Margaret Atwood?

These elements are swapped with one another in the Finklestein reaction. Free radical substitutions are used to add these elements onto an alkane. Elements from this group are often mixed with inert gases to create namesake lamps. With the exception of its lightest member, elements from this group form (*) strong binary acids when bonded to hydrogen. Elements from this group tend to form diatomic compounds with themselves and each have seven valence electrons in their neutral state. For ten points, identify this group of the periodic table that includes chlorine, bromine and fluorine.

In one work, this author described a dying tightrope walker who had fallen from his rope before advocating for the breaking of old tablets representing old moral systems. This author compared human actions to a waterfall in one of the many aphorisms in the work Human, All Too Human. This author contrasted the Apollonian and Dionysian in The (*) Birth of Tragedy, and discussed the concept of eternal recurrence in works like The Gay Science. The concept of “will to power” was proposed by, for ten points, which German philosopher who described the Übermensch in Thus Spoke Zarathustra?

The Reformation in this country incited the Count’s Feud, which ended with the coronation of a ruler who converted this country to Protestantism. This country’s flag legendarily fell from the sky at the Battle of Lindanise during a campaign in Estonia, and this country fought two wars against Prussia over its territories of (*) Schleswig and Holstein. This country’s King Valedmar II wrote the Code of Jutland, this country’s first constitution. King Eric, who ruled this country with Norway and Sweden in the Kalmar Union, built Kronborg Castle. For ten points, name this country which Christian X governed from Copenhagen.
tossups.answer: Kingdom of Denmark [accept Denmark-Norway, accept Kongeriget Danmark]

tossups.question: This author advised Franz Kappus to "go into yourself" in a series of correspondences later published as Letters to a Young Poet. In one poem, this man described the title creature’s strides as a “ritual dance around a center.” In another poem by this author of “The Panther,” the title object is compared to “a wild beast’s fur.” That poem, which ends “you must change your life,” is (*) “Archaic Torso of Apollo.” While staying in a castle owned by Princess Thurn und Taxis, this man wrote a collection that begins "Who, if I cried out, would hear me among the angelic orders?” For ten points, name this German poet of Sonnets to Orpheus and the Duino Elegies.

Followers of this religion perform music with a three-drum set known as an akete. People following this religion avoid foods with chemicals and preservatives to increase the force of  “livity” in their ital diet. People are separated into “mansions” in this religion, whose major texts include the (*) Holy Piby and the Kebra Nagast. Its “reasoning” sessions often include the smoking of cannabis known as ganja. Members of this religion believe that Halie Selassie is the incarnation of Jah, or God, on earth. For ten points, name this Jamaican religion whose practitioners are famous for wearing dreadlocks.

A manufacturer of this good was the defendant in the 1895 case US v. EC Knight Co, which limited the scope of the interstate commerce clause. The slaves that rebelled in the German Coast Rebellion harvested this good, which was grown on farms owned by békés in Martinique. The Mormon-owned Utah-Idaho company produced this good from (*) beets. Centers of production of this good in the New World included Barbados and Brazil. Domino Foods produces this good, which, in the United States, is primarily consumed as high fructose corn syrup. For ten points, name this foodstuff, a sweetener sometimes extracted from cane.
tossups.answer: sugar [accept sugarcane, sugar beets, or any specific type of sugar, prompt on molasses, do NOT accept or prompt on stevia, saccharine, other other artificial sweeteners, accept sucrose]
tossups.answer_formatted: sugar [accept sugarcane, sugar beets, or any specific type of sugar, prompt on molasses, do NOT or or prompt on stevia, saccharine, other other artificial sweeteners, or sucrose]
acceptable: any specific type of sugar, prompt on molasses, do NOT
or prompt on stevia, saccharine, other other artificial sweeteners,

tossups.question: One artist from this movement painted a popular tourist destination in Moseley Weir - Morning. Alfred Sisley was a prominent English member of this movement who pioneered the usage of en plein air landscapes among its members. A painting from this movement was derided as less complete than “a preliminary drawing for a wallpaper pattern” by (*) Louis Leroy, who coined this movement’s name. Another member of this art movement painted many haystacks and water lilies, as well as a painting of a sunrise over Le Havre. For ten points, name this art movement that emphasized visible brush strokes and changing perspectives of light, which was pioneered by Claude Monet.
tossups.answer: Impressionism [accept related word forms like impressionist]

tossups.question: This family relocated from Mould-on-the-Wold after the imprisonment of its patriarch, Percival. Credence Barebone claimed to be a member of this family. Another member of this family was prosecuted for “inappropriate” behavior with goats and owned the (*) Hog’s Head Inn. That member of this family accused his brother of killing their sister Ariana during a duel with Gellert Grindelwald. A member of this family served as longtime headmaster of Hogwarts before being killed by Severus Snape. For ten points, name this wizarding family in the Harry Potter series that includes Aberforth and Albus.
tossups.answer: Dumbledore family [accept Percival Dumbledore or Aurelius Dumbledore or Ariana Dumbledore or Aberforth Dumbledore or Albus (Percival Wulfric Brian) Dumbledore]
tossups.answer_formatted: Dumbledore family [accept Percival Dumbledore or Aurelius Dumbledore or Ariana Dumbledore or Aberforth Dumbledore or Albus (Percival Wulfric Brian) Dumbledore]

tossups.question: A character in this play claims that another character has turned into a yellow bird that is attempting to peck her face. This play ends with another character describing how her husband “has his goodness now; God forbid I take it from him.” That character is given a “poppet,” which results in her being imprisoned with (*) Rebecca Nurse. In this play, Giles Corey repeatedly demands that “more weight” be placed on him as he is crushed to death with rocks. In this play, several characters, including the slave Tituba, are accused by Abigail Williams. For ten points, name this play by Arthur Miller in which John Proctor is executed during the Salem Witch Trials.

Points where these phenomena have equal velocities are called isotachs. The piteraq is an example of a type of this phenomenon that is caused by gravity. That type of this phenomenon is called the “katabatic” variety. This phenomenon is stronger between 30 degrees and 60 degrees of (*) latitude due to the boundaries of the Hadley, Ferrel, and polar cells. This phenomenon, which is measured from 0 to 12 on the Beaufort scale, can also be measured on the Saffir-Simpson scale. A seasonal type of this phenomenon that occurs in Southeast Asia is called the monsoon. For ten points, name this phenomenon, the large-scale movement of air in the sky.
tossups.answer: winds [accept hurricane or monsoon or katabatic winds before mention; do not accept or prompt on “stellar wind” or “solar wind” or “planetary wind”]
tossups.answer_formatted: winds [accept hurricane or monsoon or katabatic winds before mention; do not accept or prompt on "stellar wind" or "solar wind" or "planetary wind"]

tossups.question: One narrative piece originally by this composer opens with rapid octave G triplets, which represent a horse galloping. This composer included “The Hurdy-Gurdy Man” in one of his song cycles based on the poems of Wilhelm Müller, Winterreise [vinter-rhy-suh]. An piano quintet in A major by this composer is nicknamed for its incorporation of an earlier piece that depicts a (*) trout. Gretchen am Spinnrade is one of this composer’s many lieder [leader], or songs. This composer only wrote two movements of his B minor eighth symphony before stopping work on it. For ten points, name this Romantic composer of the Unfinished Symphony.
tossups.answer: Franz Peter Schubert [the first clue refers to “Erlkönig”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Franz Peter Schubert [the first clue refers to “Erlkönig”]

bonuses.leadin: This painting was inspired by the true story of the Zong, which appears in the distance on the left of the painting. For ten points each:
answers: United Kingdom [or Great Britain or England]
parts: Name this work in which sharks pursue bodies floating in the wake of the title object while the sun sets in the background.
This artist of The Slave Ship painted a rowboat on the Thames while a rabbit can be seen running alongside a train in Rain, Steam, and Speed.
Turner was a Romantic painter from this country. Another of his paintings depicted a fire burning this country’s Houses of Parliament.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about baseball players who hold nearly unbeatable records:
answers: Nolan Ryan [or Lynn Nolan Ryan, Jr.; accept The Ryan Express]
grand slam [prompt on descriptions of a four-run home run; do not accept or prompt on “home run”]
San Francisco Giants [accept either underlined part]
parts: This pitcher holds the Major League record for both strikeouts and walks allowed, which he accumulated over a 27 year career. He also threw a record seven no-hitters, although none of them were perfect games.
Fernando Tatís Sr. achieved this feat twice in one inning in 1999, becoming the only professional player to ever do so. This type of hit scores the most runs possible on a single play

In his 2004 season, Barry Bonds destroyed the single-season records for walks and intentional walks drawn while playing for this team. This team contests the Bay Bridge Series with the neighboring Oakland Athletics.
answers_formatted: Nolan Ryan [or Lynn Nolan Ryan, Jr.; accept The Ryan Express]
grand slam [prompt on descriptions of a four-run home run; do not accept or prompt on "home run"]
promptable: descriptions of a four-run home run

bonuses.leadin: One queen of this country may have killed a Huguenot woman with a pair of poisoned gloves. For ten points each:
answers: Kingdom of France [accept French Republic or Royaume de France or République française]
parts: Name this country. Its queen, Marie Antoinette, lived in the palace of Versailles, before being convicted of high treason by the Revolutionary Tribunal and summarily guillotined.

This woman was queen of France before annulling her marriage and marrying Henry II to becoming queen of England. This woman, whose grandfather William was the first troubadour, helped develop the ideals of courtly love.

Two queens of France, Catherine and Marie, hailed from this family. One member of this family, which came to power after the Ciompi revolt, supported artists including Filippo Brunelleschi in a contest to design a dome for a cathedral.
answers_formatted: Kingdom of France [accept French Republic or Royaume de France or République française]

bonuses.leadin: A quatrain in this poem ends with the line “Oh, Wilderness were Paradise enow!”. For ten points each:
parts: Name this lengthy poem originally written by Omar Khayyam. It was notably translated by Edward Fitzgerald and contains the verse “A Jug of Wine, a Loaf of Bread--and Thou.”
The Rubaiyat was written in this language. Today, it is the official language of Iran.

This witty British author took his pen name from a cupbearer in the Rubaiyat. He wrote about Vera Sappleton in the story “The Open Window,” and about the rivals Ulrich and Georg in his story “The Interlopers.”

bonuses.leadin: For a second order reaction, this quantity is inversely proportional to the initial reactant concentration. For ten points each:
answers: reaction intermediates [do not accept or prompt on “catalysts” or “transition states”]
parts: Identify this quantity equal to the time required for a sample to reduce to 50 percent of its original amount. This quantity is often used when describing radioactive decay.
In a first order reaction, the half-life is equal to the natural logarithm of two divided by this quantity. The units of this quantity are dependent on the order of a reaction.

In a reaction mechanism, these species are produced in one step and are then later consumed, and are thus not considered reactants or products. These species are represented by saddle points on a reaction energy diagram.
answers_formatted: reaction intermediates [do not accept or prompt on "catalysts" or "transition states"]

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about cyborg anthropology, the anthropology studying the interaction between human and technology. For ten points each:
parts: Recently in the field, professor Kathleen Richardson conducted ethnographic research on humans interacting with this field of computer science that seeks to imitate functions of the human brain.

Researchers have debated whether government sanctions such as this principle, where all Internet Service Providers must treat all Internet equality and not discriminate over different conditions, have an impact on creating “cyborgs” out of people.

Researchers have concluded that this label adopted by political parties in many countries is a result of human reliance on technology. This label that supports civil rights, reform of copyright, free sharing of knowledge, and information privacy was first established as a political party in Sweden. ANSWER; pirate party <ARK, Social Science>  7. This language was used by a pseudonymous author to write a tetralogy of novels about Lila and Lenu, the Neapolitan novels. For ten points each: [10] Name this language used by Elena Ferrante, whose real identity may be Anita Raja [ra-ya], a translator based in Rome.

bonuses.leadin: This language was used by a pseudonymous author to write a tetralogy of novels about Lila and Lenu, the Neapolitan novels. For ten points each:
parts: This Italian author wrote a novel about William of Baskerville and Adso of Melk, The Name of the Rose, as well as Foucault’s Pendulum and Baodolino.
This Indian-American author used Italian to write her book In Other Words. This author wrote a collection featuring stories such as “Sexy” and “A Temporary Matter.”
Name this property of a set of vectors where any vector cannot be written as a linear combination of the others. The basis of a vector space must have this property.

bonuses.leadin: If two solutions to a differential equation have a non-zero Wronskian, then they have this property. For ten points each:
answers: festival of lights [accept anything relating to a day celebrating light, accept lantern festival]
parts: The Wronskian is used on these mathematical constructs. These constructs are reduced to echelon form in Gaussian elimination and are used to solve systems of equations.
The Wronskian is this type of operation applied to a square matrix. For a two by two matrix with A and B in the first row and C and D in the second, this operation is given by A D minus B C.
Name this type of holiday. In Thailand, Loi Krathong is a festival of this type, in which certain objects called khom loi are released into the air.
answers_formatted: festival of lights [accept anything relating to a day celebrating light, or lantern festival]
acceptable: anything relating to a day celebrating light,

bonuses.leadin: In Scandinavian countries, lussekatter buns are made for one of these occasions, St. Lucy’s Day. For ten points each:
answers: Easter Island [accept Rapa Nui or Isla de Pascua]
parts: During this festival of light, observers may mark and decorate their homes with rangoli and diyas.

This Jewish festival of lights usually falls in the month of December, and has thus become juxtaposed with Christmas. A candle is lit on a menorah for each of the eight nights of this holiday, in reference to an oil lamp miraculously burning for eight days.
Name this Pacific island at the Southeasternmost point of the Polynesian Triangle that is home to massive stone statues known as Moai.

bonuses.leadin: Deforestation due to unsustainable farming or an uncontrollable rat population led to this island’s downfall. For ten points each:
answers: bird-man ritual [or birdman cult; accept Tangata manu]
oil spills [accept reasonable equivalents like disasters involving oil, prompt on general answers like “environmental disasters”]
parts: Early inhabitants of Easter Island also participated in this ritual where villagers would compete in a swimming competition to bring back the sooty tern egg. This ritual also names the cult that worships the creator god Make-make.
The first European to discover Easter Island was Jacob Roggeveen, an explorer from this country. Another of this country’s colonies had its capital at Batavia.

A 1969 event of this type off the coast of Santa Barbara, California led to the celebration of the first Earth Day the following year. Another of these events occurred in 1971 when the Arizona Standard and Oregon Standard tankers collided in San Francisco Bay.
answers_formatted: oil spills [accept reasonable equivalents like disasters involving oil, prompt on general answers like “environmental disasters]
acceptable: reasonable equivalents like disasters involving oil, prompt on general answers like “environmental disasters

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer some questions about the history of Earth Day:
answers: Paris Agreement [or Paris Accords; accept answers that mention  climate]
parts: Gaylord Nelson, a senator from this state, advocated for environmental teach-ins and is often considered the founder of Earth Day. An earlier senator from this state was rebuked by the Tydings Committee.
This agreement was signed by the US on Earth Day in 2016. Its principal aim was to prevent warming from exceeding 2 degrees Celsius, and the United States has since withdrawn from it.
This American playwright of The Hairy Ape depicted the morphine-addicted Mary Tyrone in his play Long Day’s Journey Into Night.
answers_formatted: Paris Agreement [or Paris Accords; accept answers that mention climate]

bonuses.leadin: In one of this author’s plays, the socialite Mildred Douglas calls the laborer Yank a “filthy beast.” For ten points each,
parts: This O’Neill play centers on a saloon where characters such as the Boer War veteran Piet Wetjoen, the ex-anarchist Larry Slade, and the wife-killing Hickey Hickman muse on their “pipe dreams.”

In O’Neill’s play Strange Interlude, characters address the audience by speaking their innermost thoughts in an example of this technique also employed by William Faulkner to relay the internal monologue of characters like Quentin and Benjy Compson in his novel The Sound and the Fury.
Mashhad boasts the Imam Reza shrine, which is the largest one of these Islamic places of worship in the world. It is estimated that twenty-five million Muslims visit the site every year.

bonuses.leadin: In 2009, the city of Mashhad was declared as Iran’s “spiritual capital.” For ten points each:
parts: From Mashhad, it's approximately an eight-hour drive to this body of water, which lies to the north of Iran. This lake is fed by the Volga and Ural rivers.
Mashhad is also connected by rail to the city of Mary [marr-ee] as well as this country’s capital, which borders Iran to its northeast.
This dynasty invaded the Three Kingdoms of Korea under Empress Wu. This dynasty’s reign, which later faced the An Lushan rebellion, is often considered the golden age of China.

bonuses.leadin: Korea’s location between China and Japan has made it a target for invasion throughout history. For ten points each:
answers: Toyotomi Hideyoshi [accept either underlined name and in either order, accept Hashiba Hideyoshi]
Lady Macbeth [do not accept or prompt on “Macbeth”]
parts: This Japanese daimyo launched two invasions of Korea in 1592 and 1597. This second “Great Unifier” consolidated power after defeating Shibata Katsuie at the Battle of Shizugatake.

This international body’s Security Council sided with South Korea during the Korean War. Resolution 82 committed this body’s troops, known as peacekeepers, to combat North Korea’s invasion of the South.
Name this Scottish noblewoman from a Shakespeare play who convinces her husband to commit regicide by telling him to “screw your courage to the sticking place.”
answers_formatted: Toyotomi Hideyoshi [accept either underlined name or in either order, or Hashiba Hideyoshi]
Lady Macbeth [do not accept or prompt on "Macbeth"]

bonuses.leadin: This woman goes mad and dies after not being able to remove a “damned spot” that represents her guilt, which prompts her husband to give the “tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow” monologue. For ten points each:
parts: Lady Macbeth urges Macbeth to kill this man, the king of Scotland. Lady Macbeth says that she would have killed this man if he did not look like her father.

Macbeth eventually kills this Thane of Lochaber and friend of his. This father of Fleance had earlier seen the witches' prophecy that Macbeth would become king. During a feast, Macbeth panics after seeing the ghost of this man, and Lady Macbeth expresses anger at his fear.

Name this type of space where all frames of reference will not alter the total distance in spacetime between events. This type of space is created by combining Euclidean space and time into a four dimensional manifold.

bonuses.leadin: This type of space describes a flat surface containing no mass, unlike curved spacetime in which gravity is present. For ten points each:
answers: special relativity [prompt on relativity or SR; do not accept or prompt on “general relativity”]
parts: Minkowski space is often utilized in conjunction with this theory. This 1905 theory, postulated by Albert Einstein, explains length contraction and a universal speed limit and was later expanded upon by a “general” type.

A consequence of special relativity is the combination of this quantity and momentum into a four-dimensional vector. Objects with zero rest mass have a value of momentum times the speed of light for this quantity.
Name this process that can lead to “dead zones” in bodies of water. Sewage dumping is a common cause of the “cultural” form of this process that is caused primarily by humans.
answers_formatted: special relativity [prompt on relativity or SR; do not accept or prompt on "general relativity"]

bonuses.leadin: This process occurs when nutrient-rich runoff enters nearby water sources. For ten points each:
answers: fertilizers [accept natural fertilizers or synthetic fertilizers]
parts: One of the most common causes of eutrophication is runoff from these substances. Nutrients found in these substances include nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium.
The algal bloom in eutrophication can lead to a spike in biological demand for the dissolved form of this element. Humans breathe in the diatomic form of this element, which has atomic number 8.
Name this German architect who pioneered the International Style and founded the Bauhaus [bau-house] school. This architect was succeeded as director of the Bauhaus by Hannes Meyer.

bonuses.leadin: This architect collaborated with Adolf Meyer on the Fagus Factory. For ten points each:
answers: Ludwig Mies van der Rohe [accept either underlined part]
parts: The last director of the Bauhaus school was this architect, who also designed the Farnsworth House and Chicago Federal Center in Illinois. This architect came to be linked with the modernist maxim “less is more.”

Mies van der Rohe used the International Style to design the Seagram Building, which is located in this city. Major landmarks in this city include the 1,776-foot-tall Freedom Tower on the former site of the World Trade Center.

At the behest of King Minos, Daedalus designed this extremely confusing maze to house the Minotaur. Theseus used a magical ball of string provided by Ariadne to find his way through this maze and kill the Minotaur.
answers_formatted: Ludwig Mies van der Rohe [accept either underlined part]

bonuses.leadin: The legendary architect Daedelus had an extremely eventful life. For ten points each:
parts: This nephew of Daedalus supposedly invented the saw and the compass. Daedalus became so jealous of this figure that he pushed him off a cliff, but Athena saved this person and turned him into a bird.
Daedalus crafted a wooden one of these creatures for Minos’ wife, Pasiphaë. After being cursed by Poseidon, Pasiphaë lusted for a white one of these animals.
Unlike perfect cadences, plagal cadences resolve from this scale degree to the tonic, which is the scale degree of the subdominant.

bonuses.leadin: Much of common practice classical music is based on the tension between the tonic key and the key of this scale degree. For ten points each:
